title: Trump ambassador to testify in impeachment inquiry on text messages about Ukraine
text:
CLOSE House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff says the failure of a State Department official to show up at a deposition as part of House Democrats' impeachment investigation is "yet additional strong evidence" of obstruction of Congress. (Oct. 8) AP, AP

WASHINGTON – Gordon Sondland, the U.S. ambassador to the European Union, is scheduled to testify Thursday in the House impeachment inquiry about President Donald Trump urging Ukraine to investigate his political rival while withholding military aid.

When the top U.S. envoy in Ukraine called such a trade-off "crazy," Sondland assured him there was no quid pro quo, according to texts revealed during the investigation. Sondland later acknowledged that he called Trump before sending the reply.

Sondland is expected to defend himself Thursday before the three committees investigating Trump by saying he spoke with the president between those texts and relied on his assurances. Sondland's deposition under subpoena comes more than a week after the State Department blocked his voluntary appearance before the panels.

Sondland, a major Trump donor turned diplomat, is at the heart of the allegation that Trump had a back-channel foreign policy for Ukraine that involved his personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, seeking to discredit former Vice President Joe Biden. Trump urged Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky in a July 25 call to investigate Biden.

US Ambassador to the European Union, Gordon Sondland addresses the media during a press conference at the US Embassy to Romania in Bucharest on on Sept. 5, 2019. (Photo: DANIEL MIHAILESCU, AFP via Getty Images)

Sondland’s appearance comes three days after Fiona Hill, a former National Security Council expert on Russia, told lawmakers that former national security adviser John Bolton referred to Giuliani as a “hand grenade who is going to blow everybody up,” according to The Associated Press. Hill also said Bolton wasn’t part of whatever deal Sondland and White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney “are cooking up,” according to AP.

Texts between diplomats questioning Ukraine policy were released as part of the investigation's testimony from Kurt Volker, the former U.S. special envoy to Ukraine.

"Are we now saying that security assistance and WH meeting are conditioned on investigations?" William Taylor, the top U.S. diplomat in Ukraine, asked in a text message to Volker and Sondland on Sept. 1.

"Call me," Sondland texted back.

Taylor texted again Sept. 9: "As I said on the phone, I think it's crazy to withhold security assistance for help with a political campaign."

Sondland responded that the assertion was “incorrect” about Trump’s intentions. “The President has been crystal clear no quid pro quo’s of any kind,” he said in a text message.The Washington Post reported Oct. 12 that Sondland called Trump between Taylor's text and his own reply and that the message came from the president.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., declared a formal impeachment inquiry Sept. 24 after reports about the Trump call to Zelensky. Trump has blasted the investigation as a partisan witch hunt. The White House has notified Pelosi that the administration won’t cooperate. And Trump said he was justified in urging Ukraine to fight corruption.

Sondland’s appearance before he three committees focusing on Ukraine – Foreign Affairs, Intelligence, and Oversight and Reform – comes after lawmakers have spent weeks interviewing current and former administration officials.

More: Republicans complain about limited access to closed-door impeachment investigation sessions

Besides Sondland’s testimony, the committees are seeking messages on his personal electronics that could shed light on Trump’s relations with Ukraine. The text messages or emails were provided to the State Department, but not to Congress, according to Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, D-Calif.

The State Department directed Sondland not to testify Oct. 8. The marching orders came the same day the White House notified Pelosi that the administration wouldn’t cooperate with the impeachment inquiry. Trump tweeted that he didn’t want Sondland to go before a “kangaroo court.”

But in a statement sent through his lawyers, Sondland said he looks forward to testifying and that he “has at all times acted with integrity and in the interests of the United States.”

Taylor is scheduled to meet with the committees Tuesday.
